description: From bat (“packsaddle”) +‎ man. The element bat is from French bât, from Old French bast, from Late Latin bastum, possibly from Ancient Greek βαστάζειν (bastázein, “to bear, carry, lift”).

entries.meaning: (military) A servant or valet to a military officer.
(by extension, informal) A personal assistant or supporter.

verbs.description: batman (third-person singular simple present batmans, present participle batmanning, simple past and past participle batmanned)

entries.meaning: To act as a batman, wait on an officer.

description: From Ottoman Turkish بطمان‎ (batman). Cognate with Chagatai [script needed] (bātmān).

entries.meaning: (Turkish units of measure) A unit of weight established in 1931 equal to 10 kg.
(historical units of measure) A Turkish unit of weight varying by location, time, and item from 2–8 okas (about 2.5–10 kg).
examples: Euery bateman [in Bagdad] maketh 7. pound and 5. ounces English waight.

description: In reference to the superhero Batman.

verbs.description: batman (third-person singular simple present batmans, present participle batmanning, simple past and past participle batmanned)

entries.meaning: (slang, mountaineering) To climb up or down a rope free hand (i.e. as Batman does).
